Can you tell us a little about your system?
Our system is built mainly with CloudFormation
We modularized Serverless Application Repository for software development.
Right in the middle is the AWS account of the customer.
Via CloudFormation, we deploy IoT related services directly to the account.
In terms of the hardware, Gateway integrates the software called Greengrass.
It can collect some devices on the ground.
Through IoT Core and Rules Engine, data is finally delivered to DynamoDB.
After that, web page or mobile app might need to be developed.
We will then log in as a member
or register through Cognito.
So, after this is done, we can access the API gateway,
capture the data in DynamoDB with the Lambda function, and present it to the client.
For the other part, you can also connect to MQTT through IoT Core.
This way, you can make an instant presentation of the data sent from the device.
Or control the device through the IoT Shadow.
Two things intrigued me in this structure.
First, I see that the entire environment is available for the customerâ€™s account after developing status

Therefore, customers won't need to worry about issues concerning confidentiality
as everything is under their own control.

That's right.
Second, I see that this structure
employed the serverless feature over and over.
Can you tell us what the advantage of such feature in IoT applications is?
Sure. For IoT applications, one of the most common issues is that the customers are using
tens of thousands of devices.
Due to such huge number of connections, our main concern
fell on maintenance and operation costs.
For maintenance, our top choices are auto scaling and load balancer.
Serverless service is built on AWS's basic services.
Therefore, we don't have to worry about it. We'll  just need to focus on development,
as well as application.
Cost is another concern.
In the beginning of the operation, there aren't a lot of devices connected.
The overall expenses are then low,
since Serverless feature is billed based on the usage.
So it is cheaper at first due to small amount of usage.
However, after more devices started to connect,
based on our experiences,
programming with server will cost you more.
In contrary, a serverless system will be cheaper.
This is why serverless programming is perfect for IoT applications.
Serverless programming helps users to
have flexibility in both programming and cost,  and is perfect for IoT with numerous device activities.

Exactly. 
Finally, we know there are many IoT application scenarios,
so in your experience, what are the most common scenarios for your customers?
Our most common application lies in personnel management.
I will use a street light management system as an example.
Via Greengrass Gateway, we collect data from ground-level street lights or some environmental monitoring devices
and upload it to the cloud. After that, we employ some analytical services,
like IoT Analytics or  SageMakert of Machine Learning.
We can make analysis from the collected data.
For example, from the changes of local air quality,
we can predict that some street lights might have malfunction.
The team can then change or repair the lights before any issues occur.
Thus,  the quality of the entire IoT service is enhanced.
We can find it easier to build a smart city
with an IoT application system.
